entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 4 at 4:16PM PST until February 4 at 7:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Winter Weather Advisory, snow. Additional snow accumulations up to one inch on valley floors with 1 to 4 inches above 2,500 feet. For the Winter Storm Warning, heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations between 4 and 9 inches with up to 16 inches in higher terrain.
* WHERE...For the Winter Weather Advisory, Eastern Curry County and Josephine County including Cave Junction and Grants Pass. This includes Highways 199, 238 and I-5 from around Sexton Summit southward. For the Winter Storm Warning, Eastern Curry County and Josephine County, including the Kalmiopsis Wilderness. This includes Highways 199 and I-5 from near Sexton Summit.
* WHEN...For the Winter Weather Advisory, until 7 PM PST this evening. For the Winter Storm Warning, from 4 AM Wednesday to 4 AM PST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult to impossible. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday evening and Wednesday morning commutes.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Curry County and Josephine County

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 4 at 4:16PM PST until February 4 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Total snow accumulations between 2 and 5 inches with up to 10 inches in higher terrain. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...South Central Siskiyou County County, including I-5 from Black Butte Summit south to around Dunsmuir, Highway 89 from Snowman Summit to Pondosa and the road up to Mt Shasta Ski Park.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM PST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions will impact this evenings commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels continue to drop this evening with most areas getting some snow accumulation before snow ends. Temperatures drop with rapid freeze up tonight and icy roads.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 4 at 4:16PM PST until February 4 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations 6 to 12 inches, except up to 15 inches over the higher terrain.
* WHERE...Central Siskiyou County County. This includes the city of Hilt as well as portions of Interstate 5 from Yreka south to Weed, Highway 96, and Highway 3.
* WHEN...Until 10 PM PST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult. The hazardous conditions will impact this evenings commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snowfall rates will be up to an inch per hour through 6 pm, then should taper off.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 4 at 4:16PM PST until February 4 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the first Winter Storm Warning, heavy snow. Additional snow accumulations between 1 and 6 inches. For the second Winter Storm Warning, total snow accumulations between 5 to 8 inches with up to 13 inches in higher terrain.
* WHERE...For the current Winter Storm Warning, Western Siskiyou County, including Etna, Fort Jones and Happy Camp. This also includes Highway 96, Highway 3 and Sawyers Bar Road. For the second Winter Storm Warning, Western Siskiyou County including portions of the Marble and Siskiyou mountains.
* WHEN...For the first Winter Storm Warning, until 10 PM PST this evening. For the second Winter Storm Warning, from 4 AM Wednesday to 4 AM PST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the Tuesday morning and evening commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels should drop to include all areas by Tuesday morning.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued February 4 at 4:16PM PST until February 5 at 4:00AM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. Total snow accumulations ranging from 1 to 4 inches in southern valley floor locations, including Alturas, to 6 to 10 inches in the mountains and in NW Modoc County. Winds gusting as high as 45 mph.
* WHERE...Modoc County, including Alturas and Tionesta. This includes Highways 139, 395, and 299.
* WHEN...Until 4 AM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions will impact this evenings commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow levels remain above 4500 feet in SE portions of the area overnight into Tuesday. They should lower to all locations Tuesday evening with a rapid freeze. This could cause wet roads to become icy.

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 4 at 4:16PM PST until February 5 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Portland OR
entry.summary:
...WIDESPREAD SNOW SHOWERS FROM TUESDAY NIGHT THROUGH WEDNESDAY...
.Snow is expected late tonight through Wednesday across southwest Washington and northwest Oregon. Snow showers will be geographically dependent, and areas that receive more showers will see higher snow amounts.
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total snow accumulations up to one inch, except up to two inches at the West Hills and Chehalem Mountains.
* WHERE...Central and Southern Willamette Valley, Portland Metro Lowlands, Greater Vancouver Metro, Lower Columbia River and Cowlitz River Valleys, and Portland West Hills and Chehalem Mountain.
* WHEN...From midnight tonight to noon PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Columbia River; Tualatin Valley; West Hills and Chehalem Mountains; Inner Portland Metro; East Portland Metro; West Central Willamette Valley; East Central Willamette Valley; Benton County Lowlands; Linn County Lowlands; Lane County Lowlands; Cowlitz County Lowlands; North Clark County Lowlands; Inner Vancouver Metro; East Clark County Lowlands

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 4 at 4:10PM PST until February 4 at 7:00PM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban and small stream flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...Portions of central and northern California, including the following counties, in central California, Placer. In northern California, Butte, Colusa, Glenn, Shasta, Sutter, Tehama, Yolo and Yuba.
* WHEN...Until 700 PM PST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Water over roadways. Overflowing poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 406 PM PST, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain. This will cause urban and small stream flooding. This will result in areas of urban, small stream, and roadway flooding in the advisory. - Periods of moderate to heavy rainfall are forecast to continue through the evening. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Redding, Oroville, Red Bluff, Marysville, Corning, Orland, Willows, Maxwell, Palermo, Rumsey, Palo Cedro, Yuba City, Glenn, Shasta Lake, Anderson, Gridley, Colusa, Tehama, Ordbend and Artois. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Butte, CA; Colusa, CA; Glenn, CA; Placer, CA; Shasta, CA; Sutter, CA; Tehama, CA; Yolo, CA; Yuba, CA

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 3:56PM PST until February 5 at 7:00AM PST by NWS Eureka CA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in California...
Navarro River at Navarro affecting Mendocino County.
For the Navarro River...including Navarro...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Navarro River at Navarro.
* WHEN...From this evening to Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 23.0 feet, Flooding of Highway 128 approximately 5 miles east of Highway 1 is certain and the road will be closed. Motorists should use alternate routes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 PM PST Tuesday the stage was 21.7 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage late this afternoon to 27.6 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight to 11.2 feet Thursday afternoon. It will rise to 11.3 feet Thursday afternoon. It will then fall to 11.1 feet late Thursday evening. It will rise to 11.7 feet Friday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 23.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 26.7 feet on 03/24/2011. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued February 4 at 5:45PM CST by NWS Corpus Christi TX
entry.summary:
Areas of fog have developed across portions of the Coastal Bend. Expect visibilities generally 1 to 3 miles with a few locations seeing visibilities 1/4 mile or less at times.
Use caution if traveling as visibility may change rapidly in a short amount of time. Use low beam headlights and leave extra distance between your vehicle and others on the road.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued February 4 at 11:40AM PST until February 5 at 10:00AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Hydrologic flooding caused by excessive rainfall and snowmelt is ongoing.
* WHERE...A portion of northeast California, including the Susan River and tributaries in Lassen County.
* WHEN...Until 1000 AM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Additional rainfall this afternoon and evening may lead to secondary rises on already high rivers and streams and exacerbate ponding in poor drainage areas. While no additional flooding is forecast for the Susan River, a second rise to minor flood stage can't be ruled out if rain/snow elevation is higher than expected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1134 AM PST, Rain and snowmelt may cause minor flooding. - More significant flooding is forecast for the Pit River in Northwest Lassen County. See the separate flood warning for additional details on the Pit River. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Eagle Lake, Termo, Bieber, Herlong, Nubieber, Doyle, Susanville, Spaulding, Aspen Grove Campground, Standish, Janesville, Madeline, Crater Lake Campground, Westwood, Pittville, Chilcoot-Vinton, Hallelujah Junction, Eagle Campground, Merrill Campground and Ravendale. - Go to CNRFC.NOAA.GOV for river forecast updates. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 11:34AM PST until February 6 at 12:00PM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Moderate to Major Flooding is ongoing.
* WHERE...Along Pit River and tributaries in Northwest Lassen County including Big Valley, Bieber, and Nubieber.
* WHEN...Until noon PST Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Moderate to major flooding from the Pit river and tributaries are currently impacting Northwest Lassen County. Inundation and damage to roads, agricultural areas, and low lying homes and structures in Big Valley including Bieber and Nubieber. The water level as of Tuesday morning in Bieber is slightly lower then the February 2017 crest.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1128 AM PST, The Pit River near Canby is forecast to peak near major flood stage Wednesday. Impacted areas in and around Bieber are about 30 miles downstream of the stream gage with numerous tributaries in between. River levels in and around Bieber are expected to remain at very high for several days and increasing flows from Canby maybe counterbalanced somewhat by decreasing flows from lower tributaries. - Check cnrfc.noaa.gov for updated river forecasts. The CNRFC will update forecasts 4 times per day by 9am, 3pm, 9pm, and 3am through Tuesday night. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Nubieber, Bieber, Pittville and Ca 299 At Shasta-Lassen Co Line. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued February 4 at 7:05AM MST by NWS Missoula MT
entry.summary:
AVAMSO
The following message is transmitted at the request of Flathead Avalanche Center Hungry Horse MT.
...AVALANCHE WATCH ISSUED BY THE FLATHEAD AVALANCHE CENTER...
06:47 MST Tue Feb 04 2025 The Flathead Avalanche Center in Hungry Horse has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WATCH for the following areas:
NWS Missoula MT - MTZ001 (MTZ001)...MTZ002 (MTZ002)
* WHAT...Very dangerous avalanche conditions may develop as a complex winter storm brings heavy snow and powerful winds to the region.
* WHERE...Mid- and upper-elevation slopes in the Swan Range, Whitefish Range, Flathead Range, and portions of Glacier National Park.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 06:47 MST to Wed 06:47 MST.
* IMPACTS...New and drifting snow may build thick slabs over weak old snow. Human-triggered avalanches are likely on or below steep slopes.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Be alert for changing conditions and increasing avalanche danger. Avoid traveling on or below steep slopes. Shooting cracks and blowing snow are clear signs of danger.
Consult http://www.flatheadavalanche.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued February 4 at 5:57AM PST by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
AVWREV
The following message is transmitted at the request of the U.S. Forest Service Sierra Avalanche Center.
BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING
IMMEDIATE BROADCAST REQUESTED
06:00 PST Tue Feb 04 2025
The Sierra Avalanche Center in Truckee has issued a BACKCOUNTRY AVALANCHE WARNING for the following areas: NWS Reno NV - NVZ002 (Greater Lake Tahoe)... CAZ072 (Greater Lake Tahoe (CA))
* WHAT...The avalanche danger will be HIGH in the backcountry Tuesday through early Wednesday morning.
* WHERE...Central Sierra Nevada Mountains between Yuba Pass (Hwy 49) on the north and Ebbetts Pass (Hwy 4) on the south, including the greater Lake Tahoe area. This does not include ski areas or highways where avalanche mitigation programs exist.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 06:00 PST to Wed 04:00 PST.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous avalanche conditions exist in the mountains due to heavy snow,rain on snow, and strong winds. Widespread avalanche activity is very likely. Avalanches large enough to bury or injure people are expected.
* PRECAUTIONARY / PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...Traveling in, near, or below backcountry avalanche terrain is not recommended.
Consult https://www.sierraavalanchecenter.org/ or www.avalanche.org for more detailed information.
Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area of this or any avalanche center.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Lake Tahoe Area

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 4 at 5:16AM PST until February 7 at 11:00PM PST by NWS Medford OR
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Medford OR has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in California...
Pit River near Canby affecting Modoc County.
For the Pit River...including Canby...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and is forecast to continue.
* WHERE...Pit River near Canby.
* WHEN...From early this morning to late Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 9.5 feet, Expect significant flooding in southwest Modoc and northwest Lassen counties. 4900 cfs
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:45 AM PST Tuesday the stage was 9.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 0.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:45 AM PST Tuesday was 9.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 9.7 feet late this morning. It will then fall below flood stage late Friday morning. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.8 feet on 04/05/1955. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued February 3 at 11:10PM PST until February 5 at 10:00PM PST by NWS San Francisco CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Urban areas and small streams flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of northern California, including the following county, central Sonoma.
* WHEN...Until 1000 PM PST Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Streams continue to rise due to excess runoff from earlier rainfall. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1105 PM PST, gauge reports indicated heavy rain. Flooding is already occurring in the warned area. Between 1 and 2 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 4 to 5 inches are possible in the warned area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Santa Rosa, Rohnert Park, Windsor, Sebastopol, Cotati, Larkfield-Wikiup, South Santa Rosa Cdp, Forestville and Graton. - CGNC1 - Colgan Creek near Sebastopol and GRQC1 - Green Valley Creek at Martinelli Road are rising to Moderate Flood Stage. In addition, MWEC1 - Mark West Creek near Mirabel Heights is forecast to reach Moderate Flood Stage by Tuesday night. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
